Definition 1.1 (Nowhere dense set): Let $X$ a metric space, we say $A\subseteq X$ is nowhere dense if $Int(cl(A))=\varnothing$. (For any open set $B\subseteq X$, $B\not\subseteq cl(A)$.)

2 Properties of Bounded Linear Operator

2.1 Bounded Linear Operator and the Corresponding Space

Theorem 2.1 Let $(X,\Vert\cdot\Vert_X)$ and $(Y,\Vert\cdot\Vert_Y)$ be normed spaces. $T:X\rightarrow Y$ is a linear operator, then the following properties are equivalent:

(1) $T$ is continuous (in the sense of continuity for operators in metric spaces).

(2) $T$ is continuous at $\theta$.

(3) $T$ is bounded.

Theorem 2.2 (The space of bounded linear operators) Let $(X,\Vert\cdot\Vert_X)$ and $(Y,\Vert\cdot\Vert_Y)$ be normed spaces. $\mathcal L(X,Y)=\{T| T:X\rightarrow Y \text{ is bounded linear operators} \}$ is a normed space with $\Vert T\Vert=sup_{||x||=1}\Vert Tx\Vert$. If $Y$ is Banach space, then $\mathcal L(X,Y)$ is Banach space.

entry.content:
A note following Math-310 Algebra, EPFL.

1 Well-ordering and factorization

Axioms 1.1 Principles of integer number.

https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Equivalence_of_Well-Ordering_Principle_and_Induction

(1) Well-ordering principle: Every nonempty subset of natural numbers has a least element.

(2) (Weak) Induction principle: Let $S\subset \mathbb{N}$ which satisfies two properties, (a) $0\in S$, (b) $n\in S\Rightarrow n+1\in S$, then $S=\mathbb{N}$.

(3) Strong induction principle.

Proposition 1.2: Well-ordering principle and induction principle are equivalent.

$\mathcal{Proof}.$

$(1)\Rightarrow(2)$: Assume $S\neq \mathbb{N}$ prove that $\mathbb{N} \backslash S=\varnothing$ using well-ordering principle.

$(2)\Rightarrow (3)$ is easy.

$(3)\Rightarrow (1)$ For this part of proof, maybe it is better to recognize the $\mathbb{N}$ and $\{P(i)\}$ holds for all $i\in \mathbb{N}$ as equivalent. Choose nonempty $Y$ not satisfying well-ordering property. Denote $S=\{i \notin Y\}$, then use (3) show that $S=\mathbb{N}$.

Theorem 1.3 Fundamental theorems of arithmetic.

(1) Any integer greater than 1 is a product of primes.

(2) The prime factorization is unique up to the order of factors.

$Proof$.

(1) Assume there exists a non-empty set $A$ of natural numbers greater than 1 that are not products of primes. Then there exists a least element $m\in A$. Since $m$ is not a prime, $m=p\cdot q =\prod p_i\prod q_j$, where $p_i$ and $q_j$ are primes. Contradiction.

2 Elementary Number Theory

2.1 Euclidean division

Lemma 2.1 (Euclid’s lemma)

$Proof.$

Assume $p\nmid a$ and $p\nmid b$, $a=p_1p_2…p_m$, $b=q_1…q_m$, where $p_i\neq p, q_i\neq p$. Thus we have

If $p|ab$, then there is another prime factorization for $ab$. Contradiction.

Theorem 2.2 (Euclidean division) Let $n \in \mathbb{Z} $ and $d \in \mathbb{Z}_+$. There exist two integers $q, r \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $n = qd + r$, and $0 \leq r< d$. The integers $q, r$ are unique.

$Proof.$

(1) $\exists 0\leq r< d$, such that $n=qd+r$. Let $S=\{n-kd\}_{k\in \mathbb{Z}}\cap \mathbb{N}$. It is easy to see $S\neq \varnothing$. Thus, there exists a least element $r\in S$ such that $r=n-kd$. Assume $r\geq d$, then $r-1\in S$. Contradiction.

(2) Uniqueness. Suppose exists $0 \leq r_1< d$ and $0 \leq r_2 < d$ and $r_1\neq r_2$, such that $r_1+q_1d=r_2+q_2d$. Assume $q_1>q_2$ without loss of generality, $r_1=r_2+(q_2-q_1)d\geq d$. Contradiction.

2.2 Euclidean algorithm

Lemma 2.3 (Euclidean Algorithm) Let $n,q \in \mathbb{Z} $ and $d \in \mathbb{Z}_+$ such that $n = qd + r$, then $gcd(n,d)=gcd(d,r)$.

$Proof.$

(1) If $a|n, a|d$, then $r=a(n/a-d/a)\Rightarrow a|r$.

(2)If $a|d,a|r$, then $n=a(qd/a+r/a)\Rightarrow a|n$.

Since the divisors of $a$ and $−a$ are the same, one can run the Euclidean algorithm for $|a|, |b|$ to find the $gcd(a, b)$.

Induction step: Assume $a’=ax_1+by_1, b’=ax_2+by_2$ and $a’>b’$. Denoting $a’/b’=k$, and $a’\%b’=c’$,

Thus $b’=ax_2+by_2$ and $c’=ax_3+by_3$.

Corollary 2.5 If $a, b ∈ \mathbb{Z} $ ($a,b \neq 0$) and $d = gcd(a, b)$, then the equation $ax + by = c$, $c \in Z$ has integer solutions for $x, y$ if and only if $c \in d\mathbb Z$.

(1) If there is any integer solution, then it is easy to show $c\in d\mathbb{Z}$.

(2) According to corollary 2.4, there exists $x,y$ such that $d=ax+by$. If $c=dk$, then $c=a(kx)+b(ky)$.

Corollary 2.6 (Bezout’s Lemma) If $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$ are coprime, then there exist $x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $ax + by = 1$.

Definition 2.6 (Euler’s phi function) Euler’s totient function $\phi(n)$ is defined for any positive integer $n$ as the number of positive integers $a : 1 \leq a \leq n$ such that $gcd(a, n) = 1$.

entry.title: Properties of Finite-Dim Normed Space
entry.content:
Definition 1 Isomorphism in linear spaces. A linear transformation $T$ is called isomorphism if it is bijective.

Definition 2 Isometrical isomorphism (等距同构).

Proposition 1 Every finite dimensional normed space is isomorphic (线性同构，代数上) and homeomorphic (同胚，拓扑上) to $\mathbb R^n$.

Proposition 2 All norms on finite dimensional normed space $X$ are equivalent.

Corollary 1 Every finite dimensional normed space is complete. Heine-Borel Theorem could be generalized to finite dimensional normed space.

Proposition 2 A normed space $X$ is finite dimensional iff $X$ is locally compact, i.e. every point $x$ in $X$ has a compact neighborhood.

Proposition 3 A normed space $X$ is finite-dimensional iff its closed unit ball is compact.
